statement: The Tata Motors Group is a leading global automobile manufacturer, offering an extensive portfolio of smart, integrated, and e-mobility solutions.
The business recorded strong financial performance as all three core auto businesses turned profitable in H2.
Tata Motors is on a journey to make the future of mobility safer, smarter, and greener.
The company achieved a 24.2% increase in group revenue.
Tata Motors has stayed ahead of the competition by offering multiple green fuel options powered by CNG, electric, and hydrogen.
We have a healthier gender diversity with 8.79% of our workforce comprising of women employees.

A high impact launch, followed by consistent and conscious efforts to accelerate the Culture Transformation journey with active employee participation has resulted in improvement in overall employee engagement scores.
Tata Motors measures the success of its diversity and inclusion initiatives via different parameters.
Jaguar Land Rover has become a significant part of our business, accounting for 65.8% of our total revenues in FY 2022-23.
The finance bill of FY 2023-24 has given reduction in customs duty on machinery and capital goods, used to produce lithium-ion batteries for EVs.
The Company provides financing for vehicles sold by dealers in India.
The expected wholesale volumes under all scenarios are higher than under the reverse stress test.
The Company has committed towards leases of Plant Machinery and Equipments.
The company faced challenges with a PAT of I2,728 crore, reflecting a robust performance for the third year in succession.
The rise in interest rates and inflationary expectations have posed challenges to the business.
The company recorded a loss before tax of GBP 64 million in FY 2022-23, an improvement compared to the GBP 412 million loss in FY 2021-22.
Jaguar Land Rover's EBIT margin decreased from 5.2% to 5.0%.
The ongoing shortage of semiconductors that are crucial to our products may prolong or worsen.
We can still say challenges within our supply chain in sourcing parts or face significant price increases in the future.
Adverse economic conditions and declines in vehicle sales rates could have a material adverse impact on our business.
The global automotive industry, including the luxury segment, is facing increasing competition which could adversely affect our market leadership position.
The conflict between Russia and Ukraine could have a material adverse impact on our business.
The Company recorded inventory write-down expense of 723.20 crores.
The Company has no material associates as at March 31, 2023.
The carrying amount of goodwill has been allocated to CGU as follows.
Jaguar Land Rover aims to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2039.
The company expects overall growth to remain high in FY 2023-24, but with industry growth moderating.
The EV contribution in the portfolio is likely to increase to 25% in 5 years and reach 50% by 2030.

We expect our businesses to largely remain self-sustaining, and we aim to fund total product and other investment spending primarily with cash flows from operating activities supported by debt capital markets activities and bank funding, as required.
We expect to invest around `38,000 crores in property, plants and equipment in FY 2023-24.
We aim to launch Jaguar as a pure electric brand from 2025 by introducing the first Land Rover all electric model by 2024.
The Company expects to continue on its growth trajectory and sustain its leadership position.
The expected net periodic pension cost for the year ending March 31, 2024 is expected to be 376.09 crores.
The Company anticipates that the hedged sales will take place over the next one to five years.
The company is exposed to IT risks, including potential cyber-attacks that could disrupt business operations.
Supply chain disruptions and commodity inflation could adversely affect production volume and profitability.
The ongoing geopolitical tensions and inflationary pressures may impact the company's financial performance.
The ongoing shortage of semiconductors may materially affect our production levels.
Disruptions to our supply chains and shortages of essential raw materials, parts and components may adversely affect our production and results of operations.
We are vulnerable to shifts in global trade and economic policies and outlook.
The availability of funding may decrease in the future or we may see increases in the cost of credit.
The Company is subject to risks associated with legal proceedings and governmental investigations.
The assessment of impairment is based on forecasts of future cashflows which are inherently uncertain.
The Company is exposed primarily to fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, interest rates, equity prices, liquidity and credit risk.
The Company evaluates the impact of foreign exchange rate fluctuations by assessing its exposure to exchange rate risks.
